comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Blennerville Swing Bridge on historic OSI maps maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,481512,613268,7,9 The swing bridge is across a ship canal. Over the river is the Tralee & Blennerville Steam Railway www.geograph.ie/photo/1398746

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The windmill is from 1790, per the DIA. It was derelict from 1850.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From 1891 the Dingle light railway was running just the far side of the Mill and Windmill, as seen on the OS 25" map. I can't make out if it is present in this photo. If we could see just a little to the left... :D

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: This similar view adapted for NLI psychological evaluation NLI Psychologist: “Tell me what you see?” Flickroony: “I see a weird black splat.” NLI Psychologist: “Yes, I realize that, but what do you see ‘in’ it or what’s it look like to you?” Flickroony: “Hmmm… well… um, if I tell you what I’m thinking you’ll think I’m nuts!” NLI Psychologist: Oh no, not at all! Please, go on; tell me what you see.” Flickroony: “Alright… I see a flying donkey with no legs chasing a bee up a mid 19th century ship canal.” NLI Psychologist:..“Hmmm…

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: humphrysfamilytree.com/Blennerhassett/tralee.church.html The Church in Tralee has a long standing connection with the Blennerhassett family, and of course Blennerville vilage is named after Sir Rowland Blennerhassett, an English settler. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/5244641898/]

comment.author: 24392609@N05
comment._content: Poor Sir Rowland! He's 5th generation in a row born in Ireland, yet still described as "an English settler". humphrysfamilytree.com/Blennerhassett/contents.html
